4 Information requirements

This clause specifies the information required for representation of engineering data and product data that is based on a three dimensional model.

The information requirements are defined using the terminology of the subject area of this application protocol.

NOTE  The information requirements correspond to those of the activities identified as being within the scope of this application protocol in Annex F.

4.1 Business concepts and terminology

This subclause describes the business context for the information required for representation of engineering data and product data that is based on a three dimensional model.

The data planning model in Figure 1 provides an overview of the information requirements of this domain.

This part of ISO 10303 is supplemented with module ISO 10303-1818. This module contains a Business Object model that is specific to this part of ISO 10303. The BO model includes an information model that is on a higher level of granularity than the ARM of this part of ISO 10303 to be better suited for the communication with and understandability by experts of the domains aerospace, defense and automotive. It consists of Business Objects that represent major concepts and information requirements of a subset of this part of ISO 10303. It uses the vocabulary of the STEP modules where this vocabulary reflects the terminology of the domain experts; otherwise, new vocabulary is introduced. The relationship between the Business Object model and the ARM of this part of ISO 10303 is explained in the Business Object model module ISO 10303-1818. A technical discussion of the business object model is contained in Annex H of this part of ISO 10303.

NOTE    The business object model may be incorporated using a different mechanism in a later draft. Currently, it is included as the business object model module ISO/TS 10303-1818.

The product structure related capabilities are:
  • Basic assembly;
  • Assembly with shape;
  • Assembly with usage dependent shape of components;
  • Assembly technology;
  • Enhanced assembly;
  • Part make from relationship;
  • Product version relationship;
  • Alternate product and assembly component substitution;
  • Physical and functional breakdown;
  • Geometric placement within physical breakdown elements;
  • Solutions for physical and functional breakdown.
The product characteristic related capabilities are:
  • Basis product property;
  • Complex product property;
  • Basic classification;
  • Extended classification;
  • Materials;
  • Composite materials;
  • External library.
  • Characterized representation;
The product concept, specification, configuration and effectivity related capabilities are:
  • Product concept;
  • Product class and specification;
  • Effectivity;
  • Product configuration;
  • Specification control.
The management resource information related capabilities are:
  • Alias identification;
  • Approval;
  • Certification;
  • Contract and project;
  • Date and time;
  • Event and time interval;
  • Information rights;
  • Multi linguism;
  • Person and organization;
  • Security_classification.
The document management related capabilities are:
  • Basic document;
  • Document structure and properties;
  • Partial document and structured text representation;
  • Software.
The activity and work management related capabilities are:
  • Activity;
  • Work organization.
The rules and requirement related capabilities are:
  • Requirement;
  • Planned and evaluated characteristics;
  • Production rule.
The geometry models for the representation of the shape of a product related capabilities are:
  • External model;
  • capabilities for wireframe models:
    • Geometrically bounded wireframe;
    • Edge based wireframe;
    • Shell based wireframe.
  • Geometrically bounded surface;
  • capabilities with topologically bounded solids:
    • Faceted boundary representation;
    • Elementary boundary representation;
    • Advanced boundary representation.
  • other capabilities for solid geometry models:
    • Constructive solid geometry 3d;
    • Curve swept solid;
    • Swept solid;
    • Modified swept solid;
    • Thickened face solid;
    • Solid with local modification;
    • Solid with construction history.
  • other capabilities with topological bounded models:
    • Manifold surface;
    • Manifold subsurface;
    • Non manifold surface;
    • Compound shape representation.
other geometry related capabilities are:
  • Shape validation property.
  • Construction geometry.
  • Parameterization and variational representation;
  • Explicit constraints;
  • Geometric constraints;
  • Sketch;
  • Shape data quality criteria;
  • Shape data quality inspection result;
The kinematic related capabilities for a Part are:
  • Motion;
  • Kinematic topology;
  • Kinematic structure;
  • Kinematic state;
  • Kinematic configuration interpolation;
  • Kinematic analysis control and result.
The feature related capabilities for a Part are:
  • Shape feature;
  • GD&T representation;
  • General part feature;
  • General part occurrence feature joint;
  • Mating structure;
  • Machining features;
  • Form feature in panel;
  • Assembly constraints;
  • Assembly feature relationship;
The presentation related capabilities for a Part are:
  • Colours and layers;
  • Basic text and curve presentation;
  • Text with specified font;
  • Basic callout without associativity;
  • Associative draughting;
  • GD&T presentation;
  • GD&T presentation with association;
  • Mechanical design geometric presentation;
  • Mechanical design shaded presentation;
  • Mechanical design presentation representation with draughting;
  • Saved view;
  • Technical drawing;
  • Technical drawing with pictures.
The product as individual related capabilities are:
  • Product as individual;
  • Product as individual assembly;
  • Product as individual test;
Other capabilities not mentioned elsewhere so far:
  • Process plan;

4.2 Information requirements model

The detailed information requirements for this AP are defined in the AP module (ISO/TS 10303-442).

NOTE 1   The ARM EXPRESS index contains a complete list of all ARM objects identified in the information requirements in the AP module (ISO/TS 10303-442).

NOTE 2   The module index contains a complete list of all the modules used in the ARM of this part of ISO 10303.

4.2.1 Model overview

The following subclauses contain a business overview of the requirements contained in the AP module (ISO/TS 10303-442) as represented in the following list of modules.

4.2.2 ISO/TS 10303-442: AP242 managed model based 3D engineering

This application module shall be used to address the following areas of scope.

ISO/TS 10303-442 defines the full information model for this part of ISO 10303 by providing a single root for all of the modules normatively referenced.

4.3 Business Object Model

4.3.1 Scope

This part of ISO 10303 specifies the application module AP242 business object model. The following are within the scope of this part of ISO 10303:

  • application objects in ISO 10303:242-managed mode-based 3d engineering
  • business terminology used to describe capabilities at a higher level of abstraction that current terminology used in ISO 10303
  • business terminology that will facilitate the development of application programmer interfaces for ISO 10303:242 managed model-based 3d engineering

The following are outside the scope of this part of ISO 10303:

  • application programmer interface specific terminology
  • terminology related to other parts of ISO 10303

4.3.2 Normative references

The following referenced documents are indispensable for the application of this document. For dated references, only the edition cited applies. For undated references, the latest edition of the referenced document (including any amendments) applies.

ISO 10303-1,  Industrial automation systems and integration — Product data representation and exchange — Part 1: Overview and fundamental principles.

ISO 10303-11,  Industrial automation systems and integration — Product data representation and exchange — Part 11: Description methods: The EXPRESS language reference manual.

4.3.3 Terms, definitions and abbreviated terms

4.3.3.1 Terms and definitions

4.3.3.1.1 Terms defined in ISO 10303-1

For the purposes of this document, the following terms defined in ISO 10303-1 apply:

  • application;
  • application interpreted construct;
  • application module;
  • application object;
  • application protocol;
  • application reference model;
  • common resources;
  • data;
  • information;
  • integrated resource;
  • product;
  • product data;
  • module interpreted model.

4.3.3.2 Abbreviated terms

For the purposes of this document, the following abbreviated terms apply:

AM application module
ARM application reference model
BO business object
MIM module interpreted model
URL uniform resource locator

4.3.4 Information requirements

This clause specifies the information requirements for the AP242 business object model application module. The information requirements are specified as the Application Reference Model (ARM) of this application module.

NOTE 1  A graphical representation of the information requirements is given in Annex C.

NOTE 2  The mapping specification is specified in 5.1. It shows how the information requirements are met by using common resources and constructs defined or imported in the MIM schema of this application module.

This clause defines the information requirements to which implementations shall conform using the EXPRESS language as defined in ISO 10303-11. The following begins the AP242 business object model schema.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
SCHEMA Ap242_business_object_model_arm;
(*

(*

4.1.59 transition_code_enum   

A transition_code_enum is an enumeration of the types of continuity that can exist between adjacent curve segments when defining composite geometry.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
TYPE transition_code_enum = ENUMERATION OF
   (cont_same_gradient,
    cont_same_gradient_same_curvature,
    continuous,
    discontinuous);
END_TYPE;
(*

Enumerated item definitions:

cont_same_gradient: at the point of contact the segments share a common tangent.

cont_same_gradient_same_curvature: at the point of contact the segments share a common tangent and have the same radius of curvature.

continuous: there is simple contact continuity between adjacent segments.

discontinuous: the segments do not join.

    Product_class,
    Product_configuration);
END_TYPE;
(*

4.2 ARM entity definitions

This subclause specifies the ARM entities for this module. Each ARM application entity is an atomic element that embodies a unique application concept and contains attributes specifying the data elements of the entity. The ARM entities and definitions are specified below.

4.2.1 Activity   

An Activity is an identification of the occurrence of an action that has taken place, is taking place, or is expected to take place in the future. The procedure executed during that Activity is identified with the Activity_method that is referred to by the chosen_method attribute.

EXAMPLE 1   Change, distilling, design, a process to drill a hole, and a task such as training someone, are examples of activities.

NOTE 1   The items that are affected by an Activity, for example as input or output, may be identified within an instance of Activity_assignment.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity;
  activity_type : STRING;
  actual_end_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  actual_start_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  chosen_method : OPTIONAL Activity_method;
  concerned_organizations : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Organization;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  planned_end_date : OPTIONAL period_or_date_select;
  planned_start_date : OPTIONAL event_or_date_select;
  requestor : OPTIONAL Date_and_person_organization;
  resolved_requests : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Work_request;
  status : OPTIONAL STRING;
  supplying_organizations : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Organization;
INVERSE
  authorization : SET[0:1] OF Work_order FOR is_controlling;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

activity_type: the activity_type specifies the purpose of the Activity.

The following values shall be used for activity_type:

  • 'amendment': An Activity to add information to product data;
  • 'analysis': An Activity to determine the behaviour of an element under certain physical circumstances;
  • 'cancellation': An Activity to delete an element from the bill of material or to cancel the whole bill of material;
  • 'delivery change': An Activity to change the delivery schedule of an element;
  • 'design change': An Activity to change the design of an item or an assembly; this might include changes to the geometry or to properties of the object;
  • 'design': An Activity concerning the development of a design of an item;
  • 'mock-up creation': An Activity to create an experimental model or replica of an item;
  • 'prototype building': An Activity to manufacture a preliminary version of an item;
  • 'rectification': An Activity to correct the data, documentation or structure associated with an item;
  • 'restructuring': An Activity to create a new structure or position within a bill of material without changing the data associated with the items in the bill of material;
  • 'spare part creation': An Activity to design a spare part or to classify an item as a spare part;
  • 'stop notice': An Activity to stop the manufacturing process of an item;
  • 'testing': An Activity to test an item;
  • 'work definition': An Activity to manage several sub-activities related to this Activity by an Activity_relationship with a relation_type of value 'decomposition'.

actual_end_date: the actual_end_date specifies the date when the Activity actually finished. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

actual_start_date: the actual_start_date specifies the date when the Activity actually started. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

additional_ids: the textual definition of the attribute. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

chosen_method: the Activity_method that specifies the procedure selected to carry out the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

concerned_organizations: the concerned_organizations specifies the set of Organization objects that are affected by the result of the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Activity.

planned_end_date: the planned_end_date specifies the date when the Activity is or was supposed to be finished. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

planned_start_date: the planned_start_date specifies the date when the Activity is or was supposed to be started. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

requestor: the requestor specifies the Person or Organization that requested the Activity and the date the request was submitted. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

resolved_requests: the resolved_requests specifies the set of Work_request objects that are resolved by the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

status: the status specifies the level of completion of the Activity. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

EXAMPLE 2   The value 'open' is an example for status.

NOTE 2   The values and sequence of status are company specific.

supplying_organizations: the supplying_organizations specifies the set of Organization objects that carry out the work. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

authorization: the textual definition of the attribute.

4.2.2 Activity_assignment   

An Activity_assignment is a an association of an Activity with product or activity data. It characterizes the role of the concepts represented with these data with respect to the activity.

NOTE    This entity should not be used to represent the association of an activity with the organizations that are responsible for its execution or its management. That kind of information can be represented with instances of Organization_or_person_in_organization_assignment.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity_assignment;
  assigned_activity : Activity;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF activity_assignment_select;
  role : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_activity: the text that specifies the purpose of the association of the Activity_assignment with product or activity data. Where applicable, the following values shall be used for role:

  • 'input': the concepts represented by the items are inputs of the Activity,
  • 'output': the concepts represented by the items result from the Activity,
  • 'constraint': the concepts represented by the items influence the execution of the Activity.

is_assigned_to: the set of activity_assignment_select that are associated with the assigned_activity.

role: the text that specifies the purpose of the association of the Activity_assignment with product or activity data.

4.2.3 Activity_method   

An Activity_method is a way to carry out an Activity.

NOTE 1   There may be more than one method for producing a required result.

NOTE 2   This definition may be used to characterize a way to resolve a request for action. The concept of action request is dealt with in module Work request.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity_method;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  consequence : OPTIONAL STRING;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : OPTIONAL Id_with_context;
  name : STRING;
  purpose : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Activity_method. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

consequence: the text that describes the results of application of this method. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Activity_method. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Activity_method. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

name: the words by which the Activity_method is known.

purpose: the text that provides an informal description of the reason for the Activity_method.

4.2.4 Activity_method_relationship   

An Activity_method_relationship is a relationship between two instances of Activity_method.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity_method_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Activity_method;
  relating : Activity_method;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Activity_method_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the other instance of Activity_method that is part of the relationship.

relating: the first instance of Activity_method that is part of the relationship.

relation_type: the textual definition of the attribute.

4.2.5 Activity_method_work_request_association   

An Activity_method_work_request_association is an association between an Activity_method and a Work_request. The associated Activity_method serves as a recommended or non-recommended method to resolve the tasks specified in the Work_request. The association_type attribute characterizes the meaning of that association and the meaning of the Activity_method with respect to the Work_request.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity_method_work_request_association;
  associated_activity_method : Activity_method;
  associated_work_request : Work_request;
  association_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_activity_method: the associated_activity_method identifies the Activity_method that is recommended or that shall not be chosen.

associated_work_request: the associated_work_request identifies the Work_request that the recommended or non-recommended method applies to.

association_type: the association_type specifies whether the specified Activity_method may be used or not. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'non recommended method': The specified Activity_method shall not be used in order to accomplish the specified Work_request,
  • 'recommended method': The specified Activity_method may be used in order to accomplish the specified Work_request.

4.2.6 Activity_relationship   

An Activity_relationship is a relationship between two Activity objects.

EXAMPLE 1   The activity required to complete a work order, may be decomposed into a series of activities. Their corresponding instances would be related using instances of the Activity_relationship entity.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Activity_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Activity;
  relating : Activity;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Activity_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second instance of Activity that is part of the relationship.

NOTE 1   The related usually identifies the Activity, which is based on the definition of the relating.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the second instance of Activity that is part of the relationship.

NOTE 3   The relating usually identifies the Activity, which is based on the definition of the related, for example, derived from or dependent on.

NOTE 4   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the relation_type specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'alternative': The application object defines a relationship where the related Activity may be used alternatively instead of the relating Activity;
  • 'decomposition': The application object defines a relationship where the related Activity is one of potentially more sub-activities into which the relating Activity is broken down;
  • 'derivation': The application object defines a relationship where the related Activity is derived from the relating Activity;

    EXAMPLE 2   An Activity that is controlled by a Work_order with order_type 'manufacturing release' may be derived from (is based on) another Activity controlled by another Work_order with order_type 'design release'..

  • 'exclusiveness': The application object defines a relationship where the relating and the related Activity shall not have any overlap in time of execution;
  • 'precedence': The application object defines a relationship where the related Activity has higher priority than the relating Activity;
  • 'sequence': The application object defines a relationship where the relating Activity shall be completed before the related Activity starts;
  • 'simultaneity': The application object defines a relationship that establishes that both the relating and related Activity are considered as occurring during the same time period or shall be performed together in order to ensure consistency and enhance efficiency.

4.2.7 Address   

An Address is the information necessary for communicating, using one or more communication methods.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Address;
  country : OPTIONAL STRING;
  electronic_mail_address : OPTIONAL STRING;
  facsimile_number : OPTIONAL STRING;
  internal_location : OPTIONAL STRING;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  postal_box : OPTIONAL STRING;
  postal_code : OPTIONAL STRING;
  region : OPTIONAL STRING;
  street : OPTIONAL STRING;
  street_number : OPTIONAL STRING;
  telephone_number : OPTIONAL STRING;
  telex_number : OPTIONAL STRING;
  town : OPTIONAL STRING;
  url : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

country: the name of a country. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

electronic_mail_address: the electronic address at which electronic mail may be received. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

facsimile_number: the number at which facsimiles may be received. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

internal_location: an organization-defined address for internal mail delivery. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

name: the words by which the Address is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

EXAMPLE 1   "White House", "Buckingham Palace","Kremlin".

postal_box: the number of a postal box. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

postal_code: the code that is used by the country's postal service. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

region: the name of a region. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

EXAMPLE 2   The counties of Great Britain and the states of the United States of America are examples of regions.

street: the name of a street. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

street_number: the number of a location on a street. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

telephone_number: the number at which telephone calls may be received. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

telex_number: the number at which telex messages may be received. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

town: the name of a town. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

url: the text that specifies the uniform resource locator associated with the address. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

NOTE    The format of uniform resource locators is defined in IETF RFC 1738 [31].

EXAMPLE 3   URLs are used to identify world wide web sites, file transfer protocol (FTP) servers, etc.

4.2.8 Alternate_part_relationship   

An Alternate_part_relationship is an association between two instances of Part. It specifies that any version of the alternate part, may be used in place of any version of the base part, regardless of its usages and of its versions. The relationship established by the Alternate_part_relationship is not symmetric: if B is an alternate part for A, A is not implied to be an alternate part for B.

NOTE 1   If a part is an alternate for another part, it is understood that there is no interest in keeping track of which part, the base or any alternates specified, is used as a particular instance of the base part within a part structure

NOTE 2   An organization may track design changes for a base part, and establish effectivity conditions for the use of that base part in various assemblies to be manufactured. The use of an alternate part implies that an organization does not specify any particular version of the alternate part nor establish effectivities relating to it

NOTE 3   An Alternate_part_relationship may relate parts of any kind, provided both related instances of Part identify parts of the same part category.

NOTE 4   An Alternate_part_relationship for which the base part is an assembly involves that the entire part structure of the alternate part may be used in place of the base part and its part structure.

NOTE 5   This concept usually refers to form, fit, function, and quality. Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement

EXAMPLE 1   Two bolts of the same size are parts. One bolt has a square head and the other has a hexagonal head. The two bolts are considered equivalent with respect to form, fit, and function: they both have sufficiently close physical shape, they take up the same space when used, and they both serve to fasten two things together. Thus, one of these two bolts could be considered to be an alternate part for the other bolt.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Alternate_part_relationship;
  alternate : Part;
  base : Part;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  fulfilled_requirements : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

alternate: specifies the Part that may be used in place of the base Part.

base: specifies the Part for which another Part may be used as a replacement.

description: the text that provides further information about the Alternate_part_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

fulfilled_requirements: specifies the word or group of words describing the requirements that are covered by both the base and the alternate and therefore are the basis for the statement regarding the capability of replacing the base part by the alternate part.

EXAMPLE 2   Additional properties such as performance, noise, endurance, or reliability may also be considered as a prerequisite for the replacement in addition to form, fit, function, and quality.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.9 Alternative_solution   

An Alternative_solution is an object that identifies one of potentially many mutually exclusive implementations of a Functional_breakdown_element or of a Physical_breakdown_element. An Alternative_solution may refer directly to the object to be implemented or to another Alternative_solution object. In the latter case it serves as a refinement of the referenced Alternative_solution.

NOTE 1   An Alternative_solution may specify (through Alternative_solution_relationship with attribute relation_type having the values 'functionality' or 'realization') a set of objects that jointly form this implementation

NOTE 2   An Alternative_solution may be any combination of its specializations Final_solution, Supplier_solution, and Technical_solution.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Alternative_solution
  SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Final_solution,
                       Supplier_solution,
                       Technical_solution));
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  base_element : breakdown_element_or_alternative_solution_select;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  version_id : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Alternative_solution. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

base_element: the object, for which the Alternative_solution provides a design alternative. All Alternative_solution objects for the same base_element are mutually exclusive.

description: the text that provides further information about the Alternative_solution. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Alternative_solution.

name: the words by which the Alternative_solution is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of the Alternative_solution.

4.2.10 Alternative_solution_relationship   

An Alternative_solution_relationship is a relationship between two Alternative_solution objects the meaning of which is defined by the attribute relation_type.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Alternative_solution_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Alternative_solution;
  relating : Alternative_solution;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Alternative_solution_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Alternative_solution objects related by the Alternative_solution_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Alternative_solution objects related by the Alternative_solution_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The related object is one of potentially more components of the relating Alternative_solution. This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type;
  • 'realization': The related Alternative_solution is a means for fulfilling, either partially or fully, the requirements identified with the relating Alternative_solution. This relation type shall be used only when the relating object and the related objects are of different types;
  • 'specialization': The related object fulfils the requirements of the relating Alternative_solution in a more specific way than defined for the relating Alternative_solution. This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type.

4.2.11 Application_context   

An Application_context is a the grouping of an application domain and a life cycle stage. It identifies a universe of discourse suitable for the description of parts.

NOTE    Requirements and vocabularies vary among the industrial activity fields. This entity intends to identify such domains.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Application_context;
  application_domain : STRING;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  life_cycle_stage : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

application_domain: the identification of the applications for which an object may be relevant. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'assembly study': The object may be relevant for an assembly study;
  • 'digital mock-up': The object may be relevant for digital mock-up;
  • 'electrical design': The object may be relevant for the electrical design;
  • 'mechanical design': The object may be relevant for the mechanical design;
  • 'preliminary design': The object may be relevant for the preliminary design;
  • 'process planning': The object may be relevant for the process planning.
  • 'not specific': The object is considered as not specific of any application domain.

description: the text that provides further information about the Application_context. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

life_cycle_stage: the general stage in the product life cycle to which the concerned items belong. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'design': The concerned item belongs to the design phase of the life cycle;
  • 'manufacturing': The concerned item belongs to the manufacturing phase of the life cycle;
  • 'recycling': The concerned item belongs to the recycling phase of the life cycle.
  • 'not specific': The object is considered as not specific of any life cycle stage.

4.2.12 Approval   

An Approval is a judgement and formal confirmation of the quality of those product or activity data that are subject of the Approval. An Approval represents a statement made by technical personnel or management personnel whether certain requirements are met. The absence of approval information does not imply any approval status by default.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Approval;
  actual_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  approved_by : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Date_and_person_organization;
  id : OPTIONAL Id_with_context;
  planned_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  purpose : STRING;
  scopes : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Organization;
  status : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

actual_date: the point in time when the Approval actually became valid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

NOTE 1   In cases, where more than one person or organization has to sign off on the Approval, usually the last sign-off date corresponds to the date specified as the actual_date.

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Approval. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

approved_by: the personnel responsible for the Approval and the dates of the Approval. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Approval. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

planned_date: the point in time when the Approval is or was supposed to be performed. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

purpose: the text that completes the information provided within the status attribute, specifying the reason or goal of the Approval.

EXAMPLE 1   'released for production' or 'preliminary design completed' are approval purposes.

EXAMPLE 2   Where applicable, the following values may be used:

  • 'disposition': The referenced object is approved for series production;
  • 'equipment order': The referenced object has reached a status in which changes are subject to a defined change process and tools and other equipment required for production may be ordered;
  • 'planning': The referenced object is technically complete and has reached a status sufficiently stable so that other designs may be based on it.

scopes: the set of Organization objects for which the Approval is valid. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

status: a user interpretable designation of the level of acceptance of the object that the Approval is assigned to, in the context of the specified purpose.

NOTE 2   The approval purposes are defined within a given life cycle stage view and are typically dependent upon the approval cycles within an individual business process. For each defined purpose, generally there is a defined sequence of values for the status, usually leading towards the status 'approved' indicating achievement of the particular purpose.

4.2.13 Approval_assignment   

An Approval_assignment is an association of an Approval to activity or product data.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Approval_assignment;
  assigned_approval : Approval;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF approval_element_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_approval: the Approval that is assigned to activity or product data.

is_assigned_to: the set of activity or product data to which the Approval is assigned.

4.2.14 Approval_relationship   

An Approval_relationship is a typed association between two instances of Approval.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Approval_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Approval;
  relating : Approval;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Approval_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the first of the two Approval objects related by the Approval_relationship. If one element of the relationship is dependent of the other, this attribute shall be the dependent one.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the second of the two Approval objects related by the Approval_relationship. If one element of the relationship is dependent of the other, this attribute shall be the independent or owning one.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the text that specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The related Approval is one of the components into which the relating Approval is broken down with no implication of 'sequence' or 'dependency';
  • 'dependency': The issuing of the related Approval is dependent on the issuing of the relating Approval;

    NOTE 3   The value 'dependency' does not imply the semantics of the values 'decomposition' or 'sequence'.

    EXAMPLE 1   The Approval of an assembly may be dependent on the Approval of all of the constituents of the assembly.

    EXAMPLE 2   In two parallel sequences of approvals for two assemblies a certain approval of one assembly may be dependent on a certain approval of the second assembly.

  • 'precedence': The related Approval has higher priority than the relating Approval;
  • 'sequence': The relating Approval shall be completed before the related Approval is given.

Informal propositions:

IP1: The graph of instances of Approval, related by instances of Approval_relationship, shall be acyclic.

4.2.15 Assembly_component_relationship   

An Assembly_component_relationship is the relation between an Assembly_definition and a Part_instance representing a constituent of the assembly. The Assembly_definition and the Part_version_view that serves as 'definition' of the Part_instance shall share at least one Application_context.

NOTE    The constituent may also be an assembly.

An Assembly_component_relationship is a type of Part_version_view_instance_relationship.

Each Assembly_component_relationship is a General_assembly_component_relationship, Next_higher_assembly or a Promissory_usage.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Assembly_component_relationship
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (General_assembly_component_relationship,
                                Next_higher_assembly,
                                Promissory_usage,
                                Mated_part_association))
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_version_view_instance_relationship);
  SELF\Part_version_view_instance_relationship.relating : Assembly_definition;
  location_indicator : OPTIONAL STRING;
  placement : OPTIONAL transformation_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

relating: the Assembly_definition that has subordinate constituents.

location_indicator: the text that identifies this usage of the component in the assembly in a diagram, list, chart, or on a physical piece of equipment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

placement: the External_model_relationship or the Template_instance that specify the transformation information which is used to locate and orient the constituent in the coordinate space of the Assembly_definition. n the case of a Template_instance, the scale factor shall be omitted or set to 1.0. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

An Attribute_translation_assignment is the assignment of a translation into another language for a text attribute of an object.

4.2.20 Axis1_placement   

An Axis1_placement is the direction and location in three-dimensional space of a single axis. An Axis1_placement is defined in terms of a locating point (inherited from the placement supertype) and an axis direction; this is either the direction of axis or defaults to (0.0,0.0,1.0). The actual direction for the axis placement is given by the derived attribute z. the representation of three orthogonal axes defined in a three-dimensional reference coordinate system, which intersects at a unique point. This point defines the origin of the Axis_placement.

An Axis1_placement is a type of Axis_placement.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Axis1_placement
  SUBTYPE OF (Axis_placement);
  axis : OPTIONAL Direction;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

axis: the direction of the local Z axis. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.21 Axis2_placement_2d   

A Axis2_placement_2d is the location and orientation in two-dimensional space of two mutually perpendicular axes. An Axis2_placement_2d is defined in terms of a point, (inherited from the placement supertype), and an axis. It can be used to locate and orient an object in two-dimensional space and to define a placement coordinate system. The entity includes a point which forms the origin of the placement coordinate system. A direction vector is required to complete the definition of the placement coordinate system. The ref_direction defines the placement X axis direction; the placement Y axis direction is derived from this.

A Axis2_placement_2d is a type of Axis_placement.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Axis2_placement_2d
  SUBTYPE OF (Axis_placement);
  ref_direction : OPTIONAL Direction;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

ref_direction: the direction used to determine the direction of the local X axis. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If ref_direction is omitted, this direction is taken from the geometric coordinate system.

4.2.22 Axis2_placement_3d   

An Axis2_placement_3d is the location and orientation in three-dimensional space of two mutually perpendicular axes. An Axis2_placement_3d is defined in terms of a point, (inherited from the placement supertype), and two (ideally orthogonal) axes. It can be used to locate and orientate a non axis-symmetric object in space and to define a placement coordinate system. The entity includes a point which forms the origin of the placement coordinate system. Two direction vectors are required to complete the definition of the placement coordinate system. The axis is the placement Z axis direction and the ref_directionis an approximation to the placement X axis direction.

NOTE    Let z be the placement Z axis direction and a be the approximate placement X axis direction. There are two methods, mathematically identical but numerically different, for calculating the placement X and Y axis directions. The vector a is projected onto the plane defined by the origin point P and the vector z to give the placement X axis direction as x = (a -(a.z)z). The placement Y axis direction is then given by y = (z x x). The placement Y axis direction is calculated as y = (z x a) and then the placement X axis direction is given by x = (y x z). The first method is likely to be the more numerically stable of the two, and is used here.

An Axis2_placement_3d is a type of Axis_placement.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Axis2_placement_3d
  SUBTYPE OF (Axis_placement);
  axis : OPTIONAL Direction;
  ref_direction : OPTIONAL Direction;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

axis: the direction of the local Z axis. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ref_direction: the direction used to determine the direction of the local X axis. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If ref_direction is omitted, this direction is taken from the geometric coordinate system.

4.2.23 Axis_placement   

An Axis_placement is the representation of three orthogonal axes defined in a three-dimensional reference coordinate system, which intersects at a unique point. This point defines the origin of the Axis_placement.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Axis_placement
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Axis1_placement,
                                Axis2_placement_2d,
                                Axis2_placement_3d));
  location : Cartesian_point;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

location: the geometric position of a reference point, such as the centre of a circle, of the item to be located.

name: the words by which the Axis_placement is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.24 Breakdown   

A Breakdown is a partitioning of a product into a set of Breakdown_element objects that form explicit parent-child relationships. A Breakdown is, thus, a view of the product; it does not need to describe all aspects of that product.

NOTE 1   Parent-child relationships are represented by specific decomposition relationship entities, such as, Functional_breakdown_element_decomposition_relationship, that relate Breakdown_element objects.

NOTE 2   A Breakdown is not instantiable, its sub-classes Functional_breakdown, Physical_breakdown and General_breakdown, however, are.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Breakdown
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Physical_breakdown,
                                Functional_breakdown,
                                General_breakdown));
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : STRING;
  versions : SET[1:?] OF Breakdown_version;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Breakdown. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Breakdown. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Breakdown.

name: the words by which the Breakdown is known.

versions: the Breakdown_version objects that describe the versions of the Breakdown.

4.2.25 Breakdown_element   

A Breakdown_element is an element in one or more Breakdown objects.

NOTE 1   A Breakdown_element is not instantiable, its sub-classes Functional_breakdown_element, Physical_breakdown_element and General_breakdown_element, however, are.

NOTE 2   A Breakdown_element may be referenced from several Breakdown objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Breakdown_element
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Functional_breakdown_element,
                                Physical_breakdown_element,
                                General_breakdown_element));
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  is_relevant_for : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Application_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  version_id : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Breakdown_element. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Breakdown_element. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Breakdown_element.

is_relevant_for: the set of Application_context objects that describe the application domains and the stages in a product life cycle that are valid for the Breakdown_element. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

name: the words by which the Breakdown_element is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of the Breakdown_element.

4.2.26 Breakdown_version   

A Breakdown_version is a version of a Breakdown.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Breakdown_version;
  additional_elements : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Breakdown_element;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  breakdown_of : OPTIONAL root_element_select;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  top_element : Breakdown_element;
INVERSE
  breakdown : SET[1:1] OF Breakdown FOR versions;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_elements: the set of all other Breakdown_element objects, but the top_element that this Breakdown_version is comprised of. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Breakdown_version. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

breakdown_of: the object for which the breakdown is defined. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Breakdown_version. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Breakdown_version.

top_element: the Breakdown_element that has no parent Breakdown_element.

breakdown: the Breakdown of which it is a version of.

4.2.27 Breakdown_version_relationship   

A Breakdown_version_relationship is a relationship between two Breakdown_version objects the meaning of which is defined by the attribute relation_type.

NOTE 1   A relationship may exist between Breakdown_version objects of different Breakdown objects or between different versions of the same Breakdown.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Breakdown_version_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Breakdown_version;
  relating : Breakdown_version;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Breakdown_version_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Breakdown_version objects related by the Breakdown_version_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Breakdown_version objects related by the Breakdown_version_relationship.

NOTE 3   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship.

4.2.28 Cartesian_coordinate_space   

A Cartesian_coordinate_space is a coordinate space in which geometric and annotation elements may be defined. It is either two-dimensional or three-dimensional. An origin for coordinate values is implicitly defined. The units applicable to the coordinate values of elements defined in the Cartesian_coordinate_space are specified.

NOTE 4   Cartesian transformation objects are used to specify the relationships between coordinate spaces.

Each Cartesian_coordinate_space is a Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d or a Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Cartesian_coordinate_space
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d,
                                Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d));
  unit_of_values : OPTIONAL SET[2:?] OF Unit;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

unit_of_values: the various units in which any values are expressed. In the case where geometric elements are defined in the Cartesian_coordinate_space, there shall be at least two units specified, the length unit and the plane angle unit. The same length unit is applied to each coordinate direction. Only one unit of a kind shall be specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified. The unit_of_values need not be specified only if the Cartesian_coordinate_space belongs to an External_model.

NOTE    If elements with different units are required, they have to be separated into different models with their own Cartesian_coordinate_space.

A length measure unit measured in inches and an angle measure unit measured in degrees are examples for two members of the attribute unit_of_values assigned to the same Cartesian_coordinate_space. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.29 Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d   

A Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d is a two-dimensional coordinate space. Any two-dimensional geometric and annotation element shall be defined in a Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d.

A Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d is a type of Cartesian_coordinate_space.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Cartesian_coordinate_space_2d
  SUBTYPE OF (Cartesian_coordinate_space);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.30 Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d   

A Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d is a three-dimensional coordinate space. Any three-dimensional geometric data shall be defined in a Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d. A Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d is a type of Cartesian_coordinate_space.

A Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d is a type of Cartesian_coordinate_space.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Cartesian_coordinate_space_3d
  SUBTYPE OF (Cartesian_coordinate_space);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.31 Cartesian_point   

A Cartesian_point is a point that is defined by its coordinates in a rectangular Cartesian coordinate system.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Cartesian_point;
  coordinates : LIST[2:3] OF REAL;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

coordinates: is a list, the individual elements of this list are defined below.

  • coordinates[1]: The first coordinate of the Cartesian_point location.
  • coordinates[2]: The second coordinate of the Cartesian_point location.
  • coordinates[3]: The third coordinate of the Cartesian_point location; this will not exist in the case of a two-dimensional point.

name: the words by which the Cartesian_point is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.32 Centre_of_mass   

A Centre_of_mass is a type of Shape_dependent_property that is the centre of the mass of a body. The relative position of the Centre_of_mass within the body is an invariant datum relative to rotation and translation. The Centre_of_mass is a characteristic of a part, not its shape.

NOTE 1   If a shape representation is present, the Centre_of_mass is usually derivable from the shape representation. However, as a characteristic of a part, it may be pre-defined in order to reflect a requirement.

NOTE 2   In order to convey the information about the actual centre of mass of a geometric model, the use of General_shape_dependent_property with value 'centroid' for its attribute property_type is appropriate.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Centre_of_mass
  SUBTYPE OF (Shape_dependent_property);
  SELF\Shape_dependent_property.is_defined_in : Cartesian_coordinate_space;
  centre_point : Cartesian_point;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

is_defined_in: the Cartesian_coordinate_space in which the property is applicable.

NOTE 3   The values of geometry related properties are specified relative to a Cartesian_coordinate_space.

EXAMPLE    A Centre_of_mass may be specified in different coordinate spaces for different dimensioning applications.

centre_point: a point in three-dimensional space that defines the location of a Centre_of_mass in the Cartesian_coordinate_space.

4.2.33 Certification   

A Certification is a certificate. It asserts satisfaction of particular quality criteria.

NOTE    Certification information can be attached to any aspect of product or activity data.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Certification;
  certification_type : STRING;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  name : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

certification_type: the text that identifies the kind of the Certification.

EXAMPLE 1   'supplier certificate' is an example of a certification_type.

description: the text that provides further information about the Certification. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

name: the words by which the Certification is known.

EXAMPLE 2   'AP 242 certified' is an example of a name that can be used to indicate a certification of a STEP interface.

EXAMPLE 3   'ISO 9000' is an example of a name that can be used to indicate that a product has been developed following ISO 9000 directives.

4.2.34 Certification_assignment   

A Certification_assignment is an association of a Certification with activity or product data.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Certification_assignment;
  assigned_certification : Certification;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF certified_element_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_certification: the Certification that is assigned to activity or product data.

is_assigned_to: the set of activity or product data to which the Certification is assigned.

4.2.35 Characteristic_assignment   

A Characteristic_assignment is an actual attribute value for a given Class_attribute in the context of a Class_assignment.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Characteristic_assignment;
  actual_value : Property;
  attribute : Class_attribute;
  class_assignment_context : Class_assignment;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

actual_value: the actual value of the specified Class_attribute.

attribute: the Class_attribute.

class_assignment_context: the context of the Characteristic_assignment.

description: the text that provides further information about the Characteristic_assignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.36 Circular_path   

A Circular_path is a type of Path_segment that describes a direction of travel along an arc of constant radius around an axis. A Circular_path gives a circle for the translational part of the motion of the origin of the frame of a kinematic link. The interpolation for the orientation of the frame is performed in synchronous fashion with the interpolation of the translation.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Circular_path
  SUBTYPE OF (Path_segment);
  via_point : Cartesian_point;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

via_point: an intermediate Cartesian_point through which the Circular_path passes.

4.2.37 Class   

A Class is a classification of an object which characterizes all objects of the same kind; such a classification is independent from the application of the classified object.

EXAMPLE 1   A fastener with subclasses, such as fastener with 2 or 3 fixture holes, a bracket with subclasses, e.g., with 90 or 100 degrees bending angle, or screws with subclasses such as metal screws or machine screws are examples for Class.

EXAMPLE 2   For facilitating an effective part retrieval for slotted screws, several Class objects may be defined to classify screws:

  • A Class *1 with description 'slotted screws' and three subclasses with the descriptions *2: 'slotted cheese head screws - product grade A', *3: 'slotted pan head screws - product grade A', and *4: 'slotted countersunk flat head screws - product grade A'.
  • Each of the Class objects is based on a Class that further defines where the definition of the Class comes from. For Class *1 this is a company internal Class_system for 'screw classes'. For the other Class objects these are ISO standardized Class_system objects, namely for *2 'ISO 1207', for *3 'ISO 1580', and for *4 'ISO 2010'.
  • The Class objects may be characterized further by Class_attribute objects. According to ISO 1207, the Class *2 has the attributes *11 with id 'd' and description 'thread', *12 with id 'l' and description 'nominal length', *13 with id 'mechanical properties' and description 'property class', etc. The possible values 'M1.6', 'M2', ..., 'M10' for Class_attribute *11 may be defined as Property objects in a set of the attribute allowed_values. The according specification is given as name of the AO Property_value referenced by specified_value. The Property refer as their definition to a General_property_definition with the property_type 'nominal metric thread diameter'.
  • To identify the designation 'Cheese head screw ISO 1207 - M5 x 20 x 4.8', a subclass of Class *2 is defined with the same description and classification source and the description 'slotted cheese head screws ISO 1207 -M5 x 20 x 4.8' but with the values for Class_attribute corresponding to *11 restricted to 'M5' only, i.e., to get just the M5 screws, corresponding to *12 restricted to value '20' only, and corresponding to *13 restricted to value '4.8' only (for steel according to ISO 898-1 [7]).

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  defined_in : OPTIONAL Class_system;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  source : OPTIONAL class_source_select;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
INVERSE
  attributes : SET[0:?] OF Class_attribute FOR class;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

defined_in: the Class_system that contains the information about the definition of the classification and how to interpret the name of the Class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

EXAMPLE 3   'fastener with 2 fixture holes' or 'bracket with 90 degree bending angle' are examples for description.

id: the identifier for the Class.

name: the words by which the Class is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

source: the Library_reference or the Plib_class_reference that contains the specification of the Class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of the Class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

attributes: the Class_attribute objects associated with the Class.

4.2.38 Class_assignment   

A Class_assignment is an object that associates a Class with one or more objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_assignment;
  assigned_class : Class;
  definitional : OPTIONAL BOOLEAN;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF classified_element_select;
  role : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_class: the Class object that provides classification information.

definitional: specifies whether a Class serves as definition. A value of 'true' indicates that the Class is definitional. The 'assigned_class' does not take precedence over the descriptions of the 'is_assigned_to' made using Property_value or Geometric_model objects. The attribute definitional shall only be used, if the is_assigned_to object is of one of the types Material_identification, Part, Part_version, or Part_version_view. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

is_assigned_to: the objects that are classified.

role: the relationship between the Class and the associated object. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'electromagnetic compatibility': The associated object is the classification that categorizes the classified element in respect of its ability to comply with requirements concerning electromagnetic interference;
  • 'environmental conditions': The associated object is the classification that categorizes the classified element with respect to its ability to comply with environmental impact requirements.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.39 Class_attribute   

A Class_attribute is a characteristic used to classify an object associated with the corresponding Class. The definition attribute of each allowed_values shall refer to the Property_definition identified within attribute_definition.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_attribute;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  allowed_values : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Property;
  attribute_definition : Property_definition;
  class : Class;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Class_attribute. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

allowed_values: the set of Property objects that represent characteristic values of the Class_attribute. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

attribute_definition: the Property_definition that characterizes the allowed_values.

NOTE    The specification of compound characteristics can be realized by using Property_definition_relationship with relation_type 'peer' or 'decomposition'.

class: the Class the Class_attribute is a characteristic of.

description: the text that provides further information about the Class_attribute. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Class_attribute.

EXAMPLE 1   'a' or 'b' for length or width attributes or 'r' for radius attributes are examples for identifiers of Class_attribute objects. The meaning of such ids is usually specified in external sources.

name: the words by which the Class_attribute is known.

EXAMPLE 2   'length', 'width', or 'radius' are examples for the name of a Class_attribute.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.40 Class_category_association   

A Class_category_association is an association of a Specification_category with a Product_class. Additionally, this assignment specifies if the usage of one or more Specification objects belonging to this Specification_category, is mandatory or optional for all products of that Product_class.

NOTE    The assignment of a Specification_category to a Product_class does not replace the association of single members of the Specification_category to the Product_class.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_category_association;
  associated_category : Specification_category;
  associated_product_class : Product_class;
  mandatory : BOOLEAN;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_category: the Specification_category that is associated with the Product_class.

associated_product_class: the Product_class for which the Specification_category is valid.

mandatory: specifies whether the Specification objects referring to the associated Specification_category have to be used or may be used (optional) for products within the referenced Product_class. A value of 'true' indicates that the usage is mandatory.

EXAMPLE    The specification category 'radio' may be associated 'optional' to the product class of a car; the specification category 'engine' is an example for a 'mandatory' association.

4.2.41 Class_condition_association   

A Class_condition_association is an association of a Specification_expression with a Product_class. The meaning of this association is specified further by the attribute condition_type.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_condition_association;
  associated_condition : Specification_expression;
  associated_product_class : Product_class;
  condition_type : STRING;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_condition: specifies the Specification_expression that is assigned to the Product_class.

associated_product_class: specifies the Product_class for which the Specification_expression is valid.

condition_type: specifies the meaning of the association. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'design case': The Specification_expression specifies a condition when a given object has to be designed and verified. This value of the condition_type is for information only and shall not be interpreted when querying design cases or usage cases. For such a query, the value of the attribute configuration_type of Configuration shall be evaluated;

    NOTE    This value may be used to precise when a given Functional_breakdown_element or a given Physical_breakdown has to be studied by the design department so that it provides solutions appropriate for the case specified by the attributes associated_condition and associated_product_class.

  • 'identification': The Specification_expression specifies a condition that enables to distinguish the associated Product_class from other Product_class objects. This value is not applicable for a top level node in a hierarchy of Product_class objects. This identification is part of the identification of all sub classes of this Product_class;
  • 'part usage': The Specification_expression specifies a condition for the usage of the components of an Alternative_solution, the usage of an Part_instance or for the application of a Process_plan or a Process_operation_occurrence in the products of the associated_product_class. In this case, the Class_condition_association shall be referenced by at least one Configuration object;
  • 'validity': The Specification_expression specifies a condition that is used to verify a Class_specification_association for the associated_product_class. That means that the Specification_expression evaluates to 'true' if the set of Specification objects is valid; otherwise it evaluates to 'false' with the meaning that the specified object is invalid for the Product_class. The associated_condition is valid for all products belonging to the associated_product_class if condition_type is 'identification' or 'validity'.

description: the text that provides further information about the Class_condition_association. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.42 Class_hierarchy   

A Class_hierarchy is an object that defines a hierarchical relationship between two instances of Class.

EXAMPLE    With Class, part families such as screws can be classified. Additionally subclasses can be built and linked to the super-category screws, such as machine screw or self-tapping screw.

NOTE    The Class_hierarchy is used to build up hierarchical structures of Class objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_hierarchy;
  sub_class : Class;
  super_class : Class;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

sub_class: the lower level of Class in a Class_hierarchy that is included in the super class.

super_class: the higher level of Class in a Class_hierarchy that includes the sub class.

4.2.43 Class_inclusion_association   

A Class_inclusion_association is an assignment of a Specification_inclusion to a Product_class. This assignment contains the information that a particular Specification_inclusion applies for all products of that Product_class.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_inclusion_association;
  associated_inclusion : Specification_inclusion;
  associated_product_class : Product_class;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_inclusion: specifies the Specification_inclusion that is associated with the Product_class.

associated_product_class: specifies the Product_class for which the Specification_inclusion is valid.

description: the text that provides further information about the Class_inclusion_association. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.44 Class_specification_association   

A Class_specification_association is an association of a Specification with a Product_class. The meaning of this association is specified further by the attribute association_type.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_specification_association;
  associated_product_class : Product_class;
  associated_specification : Specification;
  association_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_product_class: the Product_class for which the Specification is valid.

associated_specification: the Specification that is associated with the Product_class.

association_type: the kind of availability of a particular Specification in a Product_class. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'availability': The Specification is a potential characteristic of any product belonging to a high level Product_class. It is not specified if this is an option or a standard;

    EXAMPLE 1   'front wheel drive' or 'four wheel drive' are available for a product class 'Voyager'.

  • 'identification': The Specification is a characteristic that enables to distinguish the associated Product_class from other Product_class objects. This is a kind of 'non replaceable standard'. This value is not applicable for a top level node in a hierarchy of Product_class objects. This identification is part of the identification of all sub classes of this Product_class;

    EXAMPLE 2   The car body type 'limousine' is identifying product class 'S40'.

  • 'non replaceable standard': The Specification is a characteristic of all products belonging to the Product_class;

    EXAMPLE 3   'South East Asia climate zone' is a 'non replaceable standard' for a car that is produced for use in that particular geographic area.

  • 'option': The Specification is a characteristic of a product if explicitly chosen. The Specification replaces another Specification of the same Specification_category if the replaced Specification is associated with the Product_class as 'replaceable standard';

    EXAMPLE 4   'sun roof' or 'radio with CD' are common options proposed to the customer.

  • 'part usage': The Specification is a characteristic for the usage of the components of an Alternative_solution, the usage of an Part_instance, or for the application of a Process_plan or a Process_operation_occurrence in the products of the associated Product_class;
  • 'replaceable standard': The Specification is a default characteristic of the products belonging to the Product_class as long as no other Specification of the same Specification_category is chosen.

    EXAMPLE 5   'power brake' is a 'replaceable standard' for product class 'Golf'; it can be replaced by 'ABS', which is another specification of the same specification category 'brake system'.

4.2.45 Class_system   

A Class_system is the scheme used to define the categorization of an item.

EXAMPLE    A dictionary collecting the conventional definitions of technical properties is an example of Class_system.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Class_system;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
INVERSE
  allowed_classes : SET[0:?] OF Class FOR defined_in;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Class_system. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Class_system. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Class_system.

allowed_classes: the Class objects which are defined in the Class_system.

4.2.46 Coating_layer   

A Coating_layer is a type of Shape_element.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Coating_layer ABSTRACT
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE
  SUBTYPE OF (Shape_element);

4.2.47 Collected_part_relationship   

A Collected_part_relationship is a type of Part_version_view_instance_relationship that is a mechanism to associate Part_instance objects with a Collection_definition.

*)

(*
