code: the property in the PLIB library. The format of this code is defined in ISO 13584-42.

name_scope: the Plib_class_reference in which the property is visible.

version: the identification of a particular version of a property in a PLIB library. The format of this version is defined in ISO 13584-42.

4.2.193 Point_to_point_path   

A Point_to_point_path is a type of Path_segment definition of a kinematic path by means of frames that shall be traversed. It does not include a prescribed interpolation.

NOTE 1   The interpolation is left to the software that uses the data.

NOTE 2   A Point_to_point_path describes a discontinuous motion, which is indicated by the inherited attribute transition having the value ”discontinuous”.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Point_to_point_path
  SUBTYPE OF (Path_segment);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.194 Process_operation_definition   

A Process_operation_definition is a specification of an activity that may be included in a Process_plan. A Process_operation_definition characterizes a manufacturing or control operation.

NOTE 1   Process_operation_definition as well as Process_operation_occurrence may be associated with organizational data using, e.g., Organization_or_person_in_organization_assignment. The reason for having these data available for both types of objects is the requirement to associate Process_operation_definition with organizational data in both a context independent and a context dependent way (the context is a particular Process_plan).

NOTE 2   In the case where an instance of Process_operation_definition is associated with, e.g., two Organization objects (e.g., as location), once context independent and once context dependent, the two locations need not be the same, but should be related in a way that the context dependent location should be a specialization of the context independent location (e.g., a particular assembly line in a plant).

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_definition;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  process_type : STRING;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the additional identifiers used to distinguish the Process_operation_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_operation_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Process_operation_definition.

name: the words by which the Process_operation_definition is known.

EXAMPLE 1   'operation Z10.114' is an example for name.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

process_type: the type of the Process_operation_definition.

EXAMPLE 2   'stamping', 'milling', 'drilling', 'welding', 'casting', and 'painting' are examples for process_type.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of a Process_operation_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.195 Process_operation_definition_relationship   

A Process_operation_definition_relationship is a relationship between two Process_operation_definition objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_definition_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Process_operation_definition;
  relating : Process_operation_definition;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_operation_definition_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Process_operation_definition objects related by the Process_operation_definition_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Process_operation_definition objects related by the Process_operation_definition_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'alternative': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_operation_definition may be used alternatively instead of the relating Process_operation_definition;
  • 'substitution': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_operation_definition replaces the relating Process_operation_definition;
  • 'version association': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_operation_definition is a version of the relating Process_operation_definition. In this case, only the related Process_operation_definition shall specify a version_id;
  • 'version sequence': the application object defines a relationship where the relating Process_operation_definition is the preceding version and the related Process_operation_definition is the following version. In this case, both Process_operation_definition objects shall specify a version_id.

4.2.196 Process_operation_input_or_output   

A Process_operation_input_or_output is an input or expected result of a Process_operation_definition.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_input_or_output;
  concerned_shapes : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Shape_element;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  element : process_operation_input_or_output_select;
  operation : Process_operation_occurrence;
  placement : OPTIONAL Transformation;
  role : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

concerned_shapes: the set of Shape_element objects that are affected by the Process_operation_occurrence. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_operation_input_or_output. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

element: the element that plays the role of the input or the output for the operation.

operation: the Process_operation_occurrence that the Process_operation_input_or_output is associated with.

placement: the geometrical Transformation between the local coordinate system of the element acting as Process_operation_input_or_output, and the reference coordinate system. The reference coordinate system is either the coordinate system of the reference tool, if present for the concerned Process_operation_occurrence or, if no reference tool is present, the coordinate system of the Process_operation_occurrence itself. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

role: specifies whether the identified element plays the role of an input or an output for the operation.

4.2.197 Process_operation_occurrence   

A Process_operation_occurrence is a usage of a Process_operation_definition in a Process_plan. This association states that the Process_operation_definition is part of the Process_plan.

NOTE    This mechanism enables the reuse of a Process_operation_definition in the context of more than one Process_plan.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_occurrence;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  defined_in : OPTIONAL Cartesian_coordinate_space;
  definition : Process_operation_definition;
  id : Id_with_context;
  plan : Process_plan;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the additional identifiers used to distinguishes the Process_operation_occurrence. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

defined_in: the Cartesian_coordinate_space of the Process_operation_occurrence for the case where none of the tools associated by Process_operation_input_or_output plays the role of a reference tool defining the reference coordinate space. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

definition: the Process_operation_definition that defines the Process_operation_occurrence in a Process_plan.

id: the identifier for the Process_operation_occurrence.

plan: the Process_plan to which the Process_operation_occurrence is assigning a Process_operation_definition.

4.2.198 Process_operation_occurrence_relationship   

A Process_operation_occurrence_relationship is a relationship between two Process_operation_occurrence objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_occurrence_relationship;
  cycle_time : OPTIONAL Duration;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Process_operation_occurrence;
  relating : Process_operation_occurrence;
  relation_type : STRING;
  waiting_time : OPTIONAL Property;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

cycle_time: the interval of time within which both Process_operation_occurrence objects have to take place in order to be declared as simultaneous. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_operation_occurrence_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Process_operation_occurrence objects related by the Process_operation_occurrence_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Process_operation_occurrence objects related by the Process_operation_occurrence_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_operation_occurrence is one of the components of the relating Process_operation_occurrence;
  • 'exclusiveness': the application object defines a relationship where the relating and the related Process_operation_occurrence shall not have any overlap in time of execution;
  • 'sequence': the application object defines a relationship where the relating Process_operation_occurrence shall be completed before the related Process_operation_occurrence starts;
  • 'simultaneity': the application object defines a relationship where the relating and the related Process_operation_occurrence objects are considered as occurring during the same time period;

NOTE 3   The criteria for 'simultaneity' and in particular the allowed delay between two Process_operation_occurrence objects declared simultaneous, are user-dependent.

NOTE 4   See attribute cycle_time for additional information.

  • 'substitution': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_operation_occurrence replaces of the relating Process_operation_occurrence.

waiting_time: the time which shall elapse, at least, between the completion of the relating Process_operation_occurrence and the start of the related Process_operation_occurrence. The referenced shall have a definition that is a Duration_property_definition.

EXAMPLE    The Process_operation_occurrence 'polishing' must not be started less than 2 hours after the Process_operation_occurrence 'painting' ended.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.199 Process_operation_resource_assignment   

A Process_operation_resource_assignment is a mechanism to associate a resource with a Process_operation_occurrence.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_operation_resource_assignment;
  assigned_resource : resource_definition_select;
  is_assigned_to : Process_operation_occurrence;
  placement : OPTIONAL Transformation;
  reason : OPTIONAL STRING;
  reference_tool : BOOLEAN;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_resource: the tool that is used to perform the operation.

is_assigned_to: the Process_operation_occurrence with which the resource is associated.

placement: the geometrical Transformation between the local coordinate system of the Process_operation_resource_assignment and the reference coordinate system. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

NOTE    The reference coordinate system is either the coordinate system of the reference tool (if present) for the concerned Process_operation_definition or (if no reference tool is present) the coordinate system of the Process_operation_definition itself. In the case where the value of the attribute reference_tool is 'true', no transformation shall be defined.

reason: the rationale behind the use of the resource for a particular Process_operation_occurrence. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

reference_tool: specifies whether or not the resource identified by the Process_operation_resource_assignment plays the role of the reference tool for the occurrence of an operation. In the case where the value of this attribute is 'true', all geometric transformations within the scope of the Process_operation_occurrence are defined with respect to the local coordinate system of the resource identified by the Process_operation_resource_assignment. There shall not be more than one resource playing the role of the reference tool for one Process_operation_occurrence. In the case where the resource is not represented as a Part_version_view, the value of the attribute reference_tool shall be 'false'.

4.2.200 Process_plan   

A Process_plan is manufacturing planning information, necessary to realize or produce a particular version of a Part. A Process_plan might represent a particular version of a Process_plan.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_plan;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  produced_outputs : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Part_version;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the additional identifiers used to distinguish the Process_plan. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_plan. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Process_plan.

name: the words by which the Process_plan is known.

EXAMPLE    'ABO Engine Cylinder block machining line' is an example for name.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

produced_outputs: the set of Part_version objects that are produced by the operations of the Process_plan. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of a Process_plan. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.201 Process_plan_relationship   

A Process_plan_relationship is a relationship between two Process_plan objects.

EXAMPLE    If a part shall be manufactured at two different manufacturing sites, e.g., one at Paris and the other at Bordeaux, there will be two different process plans, that may be related by a Process_plan_relationship.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_plan_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Process_plan;
  relating : Process_plan;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Process_plan_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Process_plan objects related by the Process_plan_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Process_plan objects related by the Process_plan_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'alternative': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_plan may be used alternatively to the relating Process_plan;
  • 'version association': the application object defines a relationship where the related Process_plan is a version of the relating Process_plan. In this case, only the related Process_plan shall specify a version_id;
  • 'version sequence': the application object defines a relationship where the relating Process_plan is the preceding version and the related Process_plan is the following version. In this case, both Process_plan objects shall specify a version_id.

4.2.202 Process_property_assignment   

A Process_property_assignment is a type of Property_assignment that assigns a property value to process related objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_property_assignment
  SUBTYPE OF (Property_assignment);
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF process_property_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

is_assigned_to: the objects that are described by the property value.

4.2.203 Process_state_relationship   

A Process_state_relationship is a type of Part_version_view_relationship that is a relationship between two Part_version_view objects where the relating Part_version_view is an in-process-item definition of a particular version of a Part. It characterizes a state of the Part_version that occurs before the state identified by the related Part_version_view.

NOTE    A Process_state_relationship may be used to characterize intermediate states of the Part_version, if this Part_version is one of the produced outputs of a Process_plan.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Process_state_relationship
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_version_view_relationship);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.204 Product_class   

A Product_class is an identification of a set of similar products to be offered to the market. Product_class objects that are related to each other by a Product_class_relationship do not inherit any characteristics from each other.

EXAMPLE    The following figure depicts a detail of an example of a structure that is built up by Product_class and Product_class_relationship objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Product_class;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  level_type : OPTIONAL STRING;
  market_name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  market_segment_type : OPTIONAL STRING;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the additional identifiers used to distinguish the Product_class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Product_class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Product_class.

level_type: the level of the Product_class in a hierarchical structure of Product_class objects.

EXAMPLE    A high level Product_class (level_type = 'enterprise') may be used to define all Specification_category and Specification objects for all Product_class objects of an enterprise with several brands and companies. A second level Product_class (level_type = 'platform') may be used to group all products that are based on the same technical concept (platform); these products may belong to different brands. A third level Product_class (level_type = 'car family') may be used to group all products that have a common base and a fixed set of characteristics (specification categories). A fourth level Product_class (level_type = 'car type') may represent products that are offered to the market; this level of Product_class may be defined by the marketing department. A set of specifications sufficient to produce the car is associated with its Product_class. Within this association, a distinction is made between standard characteristics (e.g. number of doors) and options that have to be chosen (e.g., outside colour) or that may be chosen by the customer (e.g., radio).

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

market_name: the words or group of words by which the market of the Product_class is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

market_segment_type: the text that identifies a marketing category of the Product_class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

name: the words by which the Product_class is known.

EXAMPLE    '69 Buick Electra', 'Bugatti Royal', 'Pacific 213', and 'Airbus A320' are examples for name.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of a Product_class. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.205 Product_class_relationship   

A Product_class_relationship is a relationship between two Product_class objects. The meaning of this relationship is specified further by the attribute relation_type.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Product_class_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Product_class;
  relating : Product_class;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Product_class_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Product_class objects related by the Product_class_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Product_class objects related by the Product_class_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'derivation': the Product_class_relationship defines a relationship where the related Product_class is derived from the relating Product_class;
  • 'hierarchy': the Product_class_relationship defines a relationship where the relating Product_class is on a higher level in the hierarchy of Product_class objects than the related Product_class;
  • 'substitution': the Product_class_relationship defines a relationship where the related Product_class replaces the relating Product_class;
  • 'version sequence': the Product_class_relationship defines a relationship where the relating Product_class is the preceding version and the related Product_class is the following version.

4.2.206 Product_configuration   

A Product_configuration is a manufacturable object, or expected as so. A Product_configuration is defined with respect to the Product_class it is a member of.

NOTE 1   The kind of product that is to be manufactured from the data of the Product_configuration, is the kind of product that the member_of identifies a class of.

NOTE 2   The intent of Product_configuration is the identification of one manufacturable object whereas the intent of Product_class is the gathering of products with similar characteristics.

EXAMPLE    A Product_configuration that is associated with a Product_class that identifies a family of diesel engines is intended to lead to the manufacture of a particular case of diesel engine, and the Product_configuration that is associated with a Product_class that identifies a car family will lead to the manufacture of a car.

NOTE 3   The entity Product_configuration corresponds to the concept of configuration item defined, in some configuration management standards, as an item subject to configuration management.

EXAMPLE 2   A Product_configuration may represent a component of a contracted product, onto which severe safety rules apply and for which configuration management is therefore rigorously applied.

NOTE 4   A Product_configuration may identify a variation of a Product_class, an entire Product_class, or some portion thereof.

NOTE 5   A Product_configuration can be established prior to the existence of a corresponding product.

For a Product_configuration one or more additional Specification objects may be specified. In this case they enhance the characterization provided for the associated Product_class.

NOTE 6   The actual set of Specification objects for a Product_configuration are obtained by the union of defining_specifications and of the Specification objects related to the associated_product_class through a Class_specification_association or a Class_condition_association with association_type 'identification' or 'non replaceable standard'.

NOTE 7   The specification of a Product_configuration may be incomplete: there may not be in defining_specifications any instance of Specification for some Specification_category declared as mandatory for the associated_product_class. For these Specification_category objects any Specification available in the context of the associated_product_class is considered as valid for the manufacturing of the product characterized by the considered Class_specification_association.

EXAMPLE 3   If the colour is not specified for a given car family, the vehicle resulting from the realization of a Product_configuration associated to the Product_class representing the car family may be without paint or painted in any available colour.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Product_configuration;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  defining_specifications : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Specification;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  member_of : Product_class;
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
INVERSE
  corresponding_part_version : SET[0:1] OF Product_design_association FOR associated_product_configuration;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the additional identifiers used to distinguishes the Product_configuration. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

defining_specifications: the set of Specification objects necessary to discriminate the Class_specification_association within its Product_class. Each defining_specifications shall be associated with a Product_class by a Class_specification_association with association_type not equal 'part usage'. The associated Product_class shall be either the associated Product_class of the Product_configuration or any higher level Product_class related directly or indirectly by a Product_class_relationship with a relation_type 'hierarchy'. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Product_configuration. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Product_configuration.

member_of: the Product_class that a Product_configuration belongs to.

name: the words by which the Product_configuration is known. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of a Product_configuration. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

corresponding_part_version: the Product_design_association that associates this Product_configuration with a Part_version.

4.2.207 Product_configuration_relationship   

A Product_configuration_relationship is a relationship between two Product_configuration objects. The meaning of this relationship is specified further by the attribute relation_type.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Product_configuration_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Product_configuration;
  relating : Product_configuration;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Product_configuration_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: specifies the second of the two Product_configuration objects related by the Product_configuration_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: specifies the first of the two Product_configuration objects related by the Product_configuration_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'hierarchy': the Product_configuration_relationship defines a relationship where the relating Product_configuration is on a higher level in the hierarchy of Product_configuration objects than the related Product_configuration;
  • 'version sequence': the Product_configuration_relationship defines a relationship where the relating Product_configuration is the preceding version and the related Product_configuration is the following version.

4.2.208 Product_design_association   

A Product_design_association is a is a mechanism to associate an Part_version with its corresponding Product_configuration. It specifies the explicit design that corresponds to the Product_configuration. The Product_design_association represents the statement that, in all definition contexts, the Part_version is a valid way to implement the Product_configuration.

NOTE    The Product_design_association might not be valid for other Part_version objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Product_design_association;
  associated_part_version : Part_version;
  associated_product_configuration : Product_configuration;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

associated_part_version: the Part_version that identifies a part which is a valid implementation for the Product_configuration, i.e. meets the requirements specified by the Product_configuration.

associated_product_configuration: the Product_configuration that represents the requirements for which a Part_version as solution is designated.

4.2.209 Project   

A Project is an identified program of work.

NOTE    A Project may be further characterized by planned or actual dates, allowed budget, or resources.

EXAMPLE    For the development of a new car, a project is set up that is responsible for the development decisions as well as for the accounting of the costs.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Project;
  actual_end_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  actual_start_date : OPTIONAL Date_time;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : STRING;
  planned_end_date : OPTIONAL period_or_date_select;
  planned_start_date : OPTIONAL event_or_date_select;
  responsible_organizations : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Organization;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

actual_end_date: the point in time when the Project was actually finished. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

actual_start_date: the point in time when the Project was actually started. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Project. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Project. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Project.

name: the words by which the Project is known.

planned_end_date: either the point in time when the Project is or was supposed to be finished or the planned duration of the Project. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If present, there shall be exactly one object that defines the planned_end_date for a Project.

planned_start_date: the point in time when the execution of the Project is or was expected to start. The value of this attribute need not be specified. If present, there shall be exactly one object that defines the planned_start_date for a Project.

responsible_organizations: the set of Organization objects that are responsible for the Project. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

Informal propositions:

IP1: There shall be exactly one object that defines the name of a Project.

4.2.210 Project_assignment   

A Project_assignment is an association of a Project with activity or product data.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Project_assignment;
  assigned_project : Project;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF project_information_select;
  role : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_project: the Project that is assigned to activity or product data.

is_assigned_to: the set of activity or product data to which the Project is assigned.

role: the relationship of the Project with respect to the object that it is assigned to. Where applicable, the following values shall be used:

  • 'project scope': the assigned objects are defined within the project, i.e. the project is the owner of the assigned objects.
  • 'project correspondence': the assigned object represents a correspondence to the project. There shall be a 1:1 correspondence between the project and the assigned object. Assigned objects are limited to be of types Product_class or Physical_breakdown.
  • 'work program': the assigned objects are carried out in the Project. In this case, the assigned objects shall be only of type Activity.
  • 'affected objects': the assigned objects are affected by the work carried out by the Project.

Informal propositions:

IP1: There shall be at least one object that the Project_assignment is assigned to.

IP2: Only one assigned object allowed for a Project_assignment with role = 'project correspondence'.

4.2.211 Project_relationship   

A Project_relationship is a typed association between two instances of Project.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Project_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Project;
  relating : Project;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Project_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the first of the two Project objects related by the Project_relationship. If one element of the relationship is dependent of the other, this attribute shall be the dependent one.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the second of the two Project objects related by the Project_relationship. If one element of the relationship is dependent of the other, this attribute shall be the independent or owning one.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: the text that specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable, the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The related Project is one of the components into which the relating Project is broken down with no implication of 'sequence' or 'dependency';
  • 'dependency': The issuing or completion of the related Project is dependent on the issuing or completion of the relating Project;

    NOTE 3   The value 'dependency' does not imply the semantics of the values 'decomposition' or 'sequence'.

  • 'sequence': The relating Project shall be completed before the related Project starts;
  • 'succession': The related Project is the successor of the relating Project.

Informal propositions:

IP1: The graph of instances of Project, related by instances of Project_relationship, shall be acyclic.

4.2.212 Promissory_usage   

A Promissory_usage is a relationship between a constituent of an assembly and the assembly itself. The relationship describes the intention to use the constituent in an assembly.

There may not be any geometric information provided for the constituent or the assembly that are associated by a Promissory_usage.

EXAMPLE    In early design stages, the Promissory_usage may be used to create preliminary BOMs for prototyping.

A Promissory_usage is a type of Assembly_component_relationship.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Promissory_usage
  SUBTYPE OF (Assembly_component_relationship);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.213 Property   

A Property is the representation of Property_definition.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property
  SUPERTYPE OF (Material_property);
  definition : Property_definition;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  global_unit : OPTIONAL Unit;
  qualifier : OPTIONAL STRING;
  specified_value : Property_value;
  value_determination : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

definition: the Property_definition that the Property characterizes.

description: the text that provides further information about the Property. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

global_unit: a unit that is valid for all Property_value that are referenced as 'specified_value' by the Property. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

qualifier: the kind of the Property. The following values shall be used:

  • 'nominal': The value is the nominal value;
  • 'specified': The value is specified;
  • 'typical': The value is a typical value.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

specified_value: specifies the Property_value that qualifies the Property by a Value_with_unit, a String_value, or an arbitrary aggregate thereof.

value_determination: information on how the Property shall be interpreted. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'calculated': The value has been calculated;
  • 'designed': The value represents a value intended by the design;
  • 'estimated': The value has been estimated;
  • 'measured': The value has been measured;
  • 'required': The value represents a requirement;
  • 'set point': The value is used as the initialization value.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.214 Property_assignment   

A Property_assignment is a mechanism to assign a Property to an object.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_assignment
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Part_property_assignment,
                                Process_property_assignment));
  assigned_property : Property;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  validity_context : OPTIONAL validity_context_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_property: the value that is being assigned.

description: the text that provides further information about the Property_assignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

validity_context: the context in which a Property_assignment is applicable.

EXAMPLE 1   A Cost_property_definition is applicable in the context of supplier A and may be different if the item is supplied by a different supplier B.

EXAMPLE 2   Software can be used in different product classes, specified by the validity_context, with different parameter values.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.215 Property_change   

A Property_change is a mechanism to describe the differences between two objects concerning the properties of these objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_change;
  added_properties : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Property;
  deleted_properties : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Property;
  described_change : changed_relationship_select;
  description : STRING;
  id : OPTIONAL Id_with_context;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

added_properties: the set of Property objects that have been added to that object of the described relationship that is identified as relating. the set of Property objects that have been added to that object of the described relationship that is identified as relating. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

deleted_properties: the Property objects that have been deleted from that object of the described relationship that is identified as relating. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

described_change: the relationship object that references a modified object and the corresponding original object.

description: the text that provides further information about the Property_change.

id: the identifier for the Property_change. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.216 Property_definition   

A Property_definition is the definition of a particular quality.

EXAMPLE    A Property_definition may reflect physics or arbitrary user defined measurements.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_definition
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (Cost_property_definition,
                                Duration_property_definition,
                                General_property_definition,
                                Mass_property_definition,
                                Material_property_definition,
                                Quality_property_definition,
                                Recyclability_property_definition));
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  allowed_units : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Unit;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  source : OPTIONAL property_source_select;
  version_id : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: other identifiers that may be used to distinguish the Property_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

allowed_units: the unit or set of units that are accepted.

EXAMPLE    A company may accept a mass specified in kilograms or tons, but not in grams or pounds.

A Property_value representing the Property_definition shall not be expressed with a Unit that is not contained in the allowed_units, if the allowed_units is specified. If specified, the global_unit attribute of a Property representing the Property_definition shall be contained in the allowed_units, if the allowed_units is specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Property_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Property_definition.

source: the Library_reference or Plib_property_reference object that defines this kind of Property_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

version_id: the identification of a particular version of a Property_definition. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.217 Property_definition_relationship   

A Property_definition_relationship is a relationship between two Property_definition objects.

EXAMPLE    A Property_definition_relationship may be used to indicate that the value of one Property_definition can be derived from the value of another Property_definition.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_definition_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Property_definition;
  relating : Property_definition;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Property_definition_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two Property_definition objects related by the Property_definition_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the first of the two Property_definition objects related by the Property_definition_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute are defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The Property_definition_relationship defines a relationship where the related Property_definition is a member of a group of Property_definition objects that is established by the relating Property_definition;
  • 'dependency': The related Property_definition is dependent upon the relating Property_definition;
  • 'hierarchy': The application object defines a hierarchical relationship where the related Property_definitionn is on a lower level than the relating Property_definition;
  • 'peer': The related Property_definition shall not be used without the relating Property_definitionn and vice versa;
  • 'substitution': The Property_definition_relationship defines a relationship where the related Property_definition replaces the relating Property_definition;
  • 'value domain': The Property_definition_relationship defines a relationship where the values assigned to the relating Property_definition shall be within the limits indicated by the values assigned to the related Property_definition.

    EXAMPLE    The output range of a 4-bit analog to digital converter is restricted to 16 discrete values, while the input voltage is restricted to a continuous range.

4.2.218 Property_relationship   

A Property_relationship is a relationship between two Property objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : Property;
  relating : Property;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Property_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the second of the two objects related by the Property_relationship.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute is defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: specifies the first of the two objects related by the Property_relationship.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute is defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The Property_relationship specifies a relationship where the related Property is one of potentially more sub values of the relating Property;
  • 'dependency': The Property_relationship defines a deriving relationship where the related Property is based on the relating Property;
  • 'equivalence': The Property_relationship defines a relationship where the related Property represents the same matter of fact as by the relating Property

    EXAMPLE 1   The distance of 1 km and 1000 m is the same. 1 km is equivalent to 1000 m, but they have different values and units.

  • substitution': The Property_relationship defines a relationship where the related Property replaces the relating Property.

    EXAMPLE 2   Property objects representing 'cycle time', 'feed time', and 'drill time' for a process may be related by a Property_relationship with relation_type 'dependency'.

4.2.219 Property_value   

A Property_value is the numerical or textual value of a Property.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Property_value
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (String_value,
                                Value_list,
                                Value_with_unit));
  name : OPTIONAL STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

name: the words by which the Property_value is known.

EXAMPLE    'l1' or 'vol2' are examples for the name of a Property_value.

The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.220 Quality_property_definition   

A Quality_property_definition is a type of Property_definition that enables to provide information about the level of quality of products or processes.

EXAMPLE    Within a prototype building activity several alternative manufacturing technologies are tested. A Quality_property_definition for the resulting parts, used tools, and the used process operations may document the level of quality reached for the parts.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Quality_property_definition
  SUBTYPE OF (Property_definition);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.221 Quantified_part_instance   

A Quantified_part_instance is the identification of the quantified occurrence of an object that is defined either as a Part_version, Part_version_view or as a Product_configuration.

EXAMPLE 1   Radiator liquid or engine oil are examples for Quantified_part_instance objects.

EXAMPLE 2   In a Technical_solution for the front left brake a certain screw is used four times.

A Quantified_part_instance is a type of Part_instance.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Quantified_part_instance
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_instance);
  quantity : Numerical_value;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

quantity: a Numerical_value specifying the quantity of occurrences. If the quantity can not be expressed as a particular value, the concept of Selected_part_instance shall be used instead to represent this instance.

NOTE    The quantity may be specified as a count measure, as a mass measure, as a length measure, as an area measure, or as a volume measure.

4.2.222 Realization_or_occurrence_relationship   

A Realization_or_occurrence_relationship is a relationship to specify the functional, logical, or physical breakdown or an alternate realization of a Breakdown_element.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Realization_or_occurrence_relationship;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : breakdown_element_or_part_instance_select;
  relating : breakdown_element_or_alternative_solution_select;
  relation_type : STRING;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Realization_or_occurrence_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: a functional, logical, or physical component or a realization of the relating Breakdown_element object or Alternative_solution object.

NOTE 1   The semantics of this attribute is defined by the attribute relation_type.

relating: the Alternative_solution or Breakdown_element object that is decomposed functionally, logically, or physically into or realized by the related Breakdown_element object or Part_instance object.

NOTE 2   The semantics of this attribute is defined by the attribute relation_type.

relation_type: specifies the meaning of the relationship. Where applicable the following values shall be used:

  • 'decomposition': The related object is one of potentially more components of the relating Breakdown_element. This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type;
  • 'functionality': The related object Functional_breakdown_element is an element of the functional structure of the relating Physical_breakdown_element or Alternative_solution;

    EXAMPLE 1   The Functional_breakdown_element 'heat dissipation' may be considered as one of the functions to be fulfilled by any technical solution for the Physical_breakdown_element 'braking system'.

  • 'occurrence': The related Physical_breakdown_element is an occurrence that is defined by the relating Physical_breakdown_element of Alternative_solution;
  • 'realization': The related Physical_breakdown_element or Part_instance is a means for fulfilling, either partially or fully, the requirements identified with the relating Functional_breakdown_element or Alternative_solution. This relation type shall be used only when relating and related objects are of different types;

    EXAMPLE 2   The Physical_breakdown_element 'braking system' may be considered as a means to realize the Functional_breakdown_element 'braking'.

  • 'specialization': The related object fulfils the requirements of the relating Breakdown_elementin a more specific way than defined for the relating Breakdown_element. This relation type shall only be used for relating and related objects of the same type.

4.2.223 Rectangular_size   

A Rectangular_size is the definition of the planar size of an object.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Rectangular_size
  SUPERTYPE OF (Named_size);
  density : OPTIONAL Value_with_unit;
  height : OPTIONAL Value_with_unit;
  width : OPTIONAL Value_with_unit;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

density: the resolution of the object if it is a raster picture. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

height: the size of the object in vertical direction. If Rectangular_size is not a Named_size the height shall be specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

width: the size of the object in horizontal direction. If Rectangular_size is not a Named_size the width shall be specified. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.224 Recyclability_property_definition   

A Recyclability_property_definition is a type of Property_definition representing information concerning the ability to reuse objects or components of objects after their primarily intended usage.

(*

4.2.225 Replaced_usage_relationship   

A Replaced_usage_relationship is a type of Part_instance_relationship that is a relationship between two Part_instance objects where the relating Part_instance is replaced by the related Part_instance.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Replaced_usage_relationship
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_instance_relationship);
  usage_context : instance_usage_context_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

usage_context: the object that identifies the context in which the replacement is applicable.

In the case where the usage_context refers to a Process_operation_input_or_output, the relating Part_instance shall be referred by the element attribute of the Process_operation_input_or_output.

In the case where usage_context refers to a Part_version_view_instance_relationship, the relating Part_instance shall be referred by the related attribute of the Part_version_view_instance_relationship.

In the case where usage_context refers to a Realization_or_occurrence_relationship, the relating Part_instance object of the Replaced_usage_relationship shall be referred to as related by the Realization_or_occurrence_relationship.

Informal propositions:

IP1: Each Replaced_usage_relationship shall be referenced by a Effectivity that defines the validity of the replacement.

4.2.226 Replaced_version_view_relationship   

A Replaced_version_view_relationship is a type of Part_version_view_relationship where the relating Part_version_view is replaced by the related Part_version_view. Each Replaced_version_view_relationship shall be referenced by an Effectivity that defines the start of the validity of the replacement.

NOTE    A Replaced_version_view_relationship may be used to build up version sequences of Part_version_view objects.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Replaced_version_view_relationship
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_version_view_relationship);
END_ENTITY;
(*

4.2.227 Requirement   

A Requirement is a used to uniquely identify a requirement.

NOTE 1   The term "requirement" is used here in the sense that term is used in systems engineering and similar industrial domains.

NOTE 2   There may be many versions of a requirement Requirement_version. The requirement entity is simply a place holder for holding a unique requirement. More associations and assignment could be done through the Requirement or the Requirement_version.

NOTE 3   Systems engineering tools and organizations may use differing identification mechanisms. Multiple identifiers may be assigned to a requirement using additional_ids attribute.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Requirement;
  additional_ids : OPTIONAL SET[1:?] OF Id_with_context;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : Id_with_context;
  name : STRING;
  owner : OPTIONAL person_organization_select;
  versions : SET[1:?] OF Requirement_version;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

additional_ids: the others identifiers that distinguish the requirement for others systems. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Requirement.

name: the words by which the Requirement is known.

owner: the Organization or the Person_in_organization that has created the Requirement. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

versions: the versions of the Requirement.

4.2.228 Requirement_assignment   

A Requirement_assignment is an object used to relate a Requirement to data types representing the items that are affected by the requirement.

EXAMPLE    A requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be assigned to the data types which are used to represent the vehicle's engine.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Requirement_assignment;
  assigned_requirement : requirement_or_version_select;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF requirement_assignment_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

assigned_requirement: the Requirement or the Requirement_version which is assigned.

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement_assignment. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

is_assigned_to: the item which has the requirement assigned to it.

4.2.229 Requirement_collection_relationship   

A Requirement_collection_relationship is a type of Requirement_version_relationship It identifies a collection relationship.

EXPRESS specification:

*)

4.2.231 Requirement_satisfaction_assertion   

A Requirement_satisfaction_assertion is a relationship between an item and a requirement, asserting that the item satisfies the identified requirement.

EXAMPLE    A data type used to represent a vehicle's engine with a power output of 160BHP could be asserted to satisfy a requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP".

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Requirement_satisfaction_assertion;

  satisfied_requirement : requirement_or_version_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

asserted_by: the Organization or the Person_in_organization that has asserted the Requirement_satisfaction_assertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement_satisfaction_assertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related_assignment: the Requirement_assignment that is satisfied by the Requirement_satisfaction_assertion. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

satisfied_by: the items that satisfies the requirement.

satisfied_requirement: the requirement that is satisfied.

4.2.232 Requirement_sequence_relationship   

A Requirement_sequence_relationship is a type of Requirement_version_relationship.

Attribute definitions:

related: the previous version of the Requirement.

4.2.233 Requirement_source_association   

A Requirement_source_association is a relationship between a requirement and the data types representing the source of the requirement.

EXAMPLE    The source of the requirement "the vehicle shall have a maximum power output of at least 150BHP" could be a document representing the findings of a market survey of sports car buyers.

EXPRESS specification:

*)

Attribute definitions:

associated_sources: the items which are the source of the requirement.

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement_source_association. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

sourced_requirement: the Requirement or Requirement_version which is to be related to its source.

4.2.234 Requirement_tracing_relationship   

A Requirement_tracing_relationship is a type of Requirement_version_relationship It identifies a tracing relationship.

(*

4.2.235 Requirement_version   

A Requirement_version is the identification of a particular version of a requirement.

NOTE    This entity is used to record different versions of a requirement. In this case, the word "version" implies "revision" - that is a particular release of a requirement.

EXAMPLE    A given requirement might have versions 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 and 2.0.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Requirement_version;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  id : STRING;
INVERSE
  requirement : Requirement FOR versions;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement_version. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

id: the identifier for the Requirement_version.

requirement: the Requirement for which the Requirement_version identifies a version.

4.2.236 Requirement_version_relationship   

A Requirement_version_relationship is a type of relationship that is used to relate previous version (related) of a requirement to the version that replaces it ( relating). A Requirement_version_relationship is either a General_requirement_version_relationship, a Requirement_sequence_relationship, a Requirement_tracing_relationship, a Requirement_collection_relationship or a Requirement_decomposition_relationship.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Requirement_version_relationship
  ABSTRACT SUPERTYPE OF (ONEOF (General_requirement_version_relationship,
                                Requirement_sequence_relationship,
                                Requirement_tracing_relationship,
                                Requirement_collection_relationship,
                                Requirement_decomposition_relationship));
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  related : SET[1:?] OF Requirement_version;
  relating : Requirement_version;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Requirement_version_relationship. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

related: the old version of the Requirement.

relating: the new version of the requirement that replace the old Requirement_version.

4.2.237 Retention_period   

A Retention_period is the definition of a period of time that product data needs to be maintained due to organizational policy or legal requirements.

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Retention_period;
  description : OPTIONAL STRING;
  earliest_end : period_or_date_select;
  is_assigned_to : SET[1:?] OF general_organizational_data_select;
  latest_end : period_or_date_select;
  start : event_or_date_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

description: the text that provides further information about the Retention_period. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

earliest_end: the point in time after which any object the Retention_period is applied to may be deleted or destroyed.

In this context deletion or destruction applies to all subordinate objects that are not referenced by other objects.

is_assigned_to: the objects whose existence is controlled by the Retention_period.

NOTE    The master document is the one for which earliest_end and latest_end are the same.

latest_end: the point in time before which any objects that the Retention_period is applied to shall be deleted or destroyed.

In this context deletion or destruction applies to all subordinate objects that are not used by other objects.

start: the point in time at which the Retention_period starts.

4.2.238 Same_time_machining_relationship   

A Same_time_machining_relationship is a type of Part_instance_relationship relationship between two Part_instance objects that specifies that those two objects shall be manufactured together within the same Process_operation_occurrence.

EXAMPLE    The following figure shows an example for this case.




Figure 3 —  illustration of Same_time_machining_relationship

EXPRESS specification:

*)
ENTITY Same_time_machining_relationship
  SUBTYPE OF (Part_instance_relationship);
  placement : OPTIONAL transformation_select;
END_ENTITY;
(*

Attribute definitions:

placement: specifies the geometrical Transformation between the local coordinate system of the related Part_instance with respect to the local coordinate system of the relating Part_instance.

NOTE    The transformation is needed to position the related Part_instance with respect to the relating Part_instance for the same time machining process.

In the case where the placement is realized by a Template_instance the scale factor of that Template_instance shall be omitted or set to 1. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

4.2.239 Security_classification   

A Security_classification is the level of confidentiality that is required in order to protect product data against unauthorized usage.
